title-group.article-title: Corrigendum to “Bioactive carbazole and quinoline alkaloids from Clausena dunniana” [Phytochemistry 151 (2018) 1-8]

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Corrigendum
to “Bioactive carbazole and quinoline alkaloids from Clausena dunniana
” [ Phytochemistry 151 ( 2018 ) 1–8 ]
Nankai Cao, Yuemei Chen, Xiaoli Ma, Kewu Zeng, Mingbo Zhao, Pengfei Tu, Jun Li ∗∗ ,

State Key Laboratory of Natural and Biomimetic Drugs, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Peking University,
Beijing , 100191, PR China

In the original publication of this paper, the biphenyl configurations of four pairs of carbazole atropisomer ( 1–3 , 6 ) were determined as ( aS ) for 1a–3a and 6a , and ( aR ) for 1b–3b and 6b , respectively. However, in following up this research, we found that it not appropriate to determine the stereochemistry of dimeric carbazoles by comparison of their ECD data with those of biphenyl lignanoids (Chen et al., 2006; Shen et al., 2007), even though their ECD curves match well. We have therefore reinvestigated the configurations of the carbazole atropisomers by ECD exciton coupling and comparison of the calculated and experimental ECD data. This has led us to propose a redefinition of the configurations.

The ECD spectrum of 1a exhibited sequential negative and positive Cotton effects at 240 and 218 nm , i.e., a negative couplet derived from the electronic transition of the two carbazole monomers as shown in Fig. 1 . Therefore, the absolute configuration of (−)-dunnine A ( 1a ) was determined as ( aR ), and correspondingly, that of (+)-dunnine B ( 1b ) was assigned as ( aS ). Further support for this conclusion was obtained when the ECD spectra of ( aR )- and ( aS )- 1 ( Fig. 2 ) were calculated using the TDDFT method at the B3LYP/6-311+G(d) level: this confirmed the results of ECD exciton coupling. Then, the absolute configurations of 2a/3a / 6a and 2b / 3b/6b were defined as ( aR ) and ( aS ), respectively, by comparison of their specific rotations and ECD data with those of 1a and 1b . Their structures were corrected as shown in Fig. 3 . The authors apologize for any inconvenience caused.

∗
Corresponding author. State Key Laboratory of Natural and Biomimetic Drugs, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences , Peking University, No. 38 Xueyuan Road, Haidian District , Beijing , 100191, PR China
.
E-mail addresses: lijun@bjmu.edu.cn (J. Li), yongjiang@bjmu.edu.cn (Y. Jiang).

sec.title: References

Shen, Y.C., Cheng, Y.B., Lan, T.W., Liaw, C.C., Liou, S.S., Kuo, Y.H., Khalil, A.T., 2007. Kadsuphilols A–H, oxygenated lignans from Kadsura philippinensis . J. Nat. Prod. 70, 1139–1145.
